text:
When I read cases
back at school,

I never fully thought I could
be one of those protagonists.
I don't know why.

I just thought there must
be something different, more

ambitious, more unique
about the characters that
get picked to be profiled.

I want to introduce Katie
Hood who's the protagonist.
Welcome.

Well, I'm the CEO of a
fast-growing startup.

So I think any CEO of
a fast-growing startup

would say that you're
doing whatever it
takes to move the ball forward.

You could start with prevention
of domestic violence.

But the real way
to think about it--

we do not teach our
young people about how
to build healthy relationships.

We do not have
conversations with them

about the difference between
healthy and unhealthy.

We go from
everything's all right

to somebody who's been
killed, and there's
a whole continuum in between.

"One Love" was created
after a young woman named

Yeardley Love was killed at the
University of Virginia in 2010.

I got involved initially because
her cousin is one of my closest

friends, and I
could see straight

up that the family had no
idea that she'd been at risk.

And they realized that better
education could have really

empowered a lot of people
around her including

herself to take action that
would have prevented her death.

And the idea was with
better education,

we can do what Mothers
Against Drunk Driving

did three decades ago and
really radically change

social norms and the
statistics in one generation.

I wanted to do
this case because I

want people to see "One Love"
as a viable and important
entrepreneurial endeavor.

I'm actually trying to
build a scaled solution.

So the opportunity
to sit with Tom

and have him try to poke
holes in various elements

or ask me hard
questions like, so when
are you going to burn out?

I'm still the primary
fundraiser for sure.

I'm constantly
selling the vision
and trying to recruit people in.

Lack of a big brand
has been one challenge.

But the most mind-boggling
challenge of them

all is how stigmatized
domestic violence is.

The money that
does exist rightly
has gone to support survivors.

Being forced to think about
those questions and to pause

and be honest with myself
was really helpful.

I feel that this is a job I
was put on this earth to do.

How am I developing and
sustaining relationships?

And then if we don't give our
kids that education that we're

like sending them out to life
with one arm behind their back

because the truth
is all the research

shows that the quality
of your relationships

will dictate your
physical health.

The famous expression you
can't be what you can't see.

If you don't read and study
a story of women leaders,

you're going to be both shaping
how men think about women

and leadership, and you're
going to be shaping how women
think about their potential.

It's not just about who the
individual protagonist is.

It's about their experience and
the relationships they've built

and what they've done over time
that gets them to that place,

and that it's actually
possible for everybody.
